original_title: Sri Lanka has achieved balance in restructuring domestic debt: World Bank official
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The World Bank believes Sri Lanka’s domestic debt restructuring (DDR) programme has achieved an appropriate balance in the trade-off between debt sustainability and ensuring continued confidence in the financial sector, a senior World Bank official said.

World Bank Country Director for the Maldives, Nepal and Sri Lanka Faris Hadad-zervos told EconomyNext on the sidelines of a talk on Wednesday July 18 that the government’s decision to go for a DDR and parliament’s approval of that decision were welcome steps in Sri Lanka’s path towards debt sustainability.

“As we’re focused on the recovery of Sri Lanka and the return to a growth path, we’re very much interested in debt sustainability. The details of the restructuring parameters and the perimeter are decisions by the government and the creditors. We’re not a part of that. Our position is that anything that achieves debt sustainability and achieves it as soon as possible will help Sri Lanka return to a path to growth,” said Hadad-zervos

“DDR as part of that is a very important thing. The decision by the government and the approval by the parliament of it is a welcome step. Within that, those decisions are for the government to undertake,” he said.

Asked about the criticism levelled at the DDR programme on the allegedly unfair burden placed on the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) and the Employees’ Trust Fund (ETF), the World Bank official indicated that a trade-off would be inevitable.

“We’re aware that there is a tradeoff between debt sustainability and making sure that there is continued confidence in the financial sector. We leave this to the government, and our assessment is that the balance is appropriate,” he said.
Sri Lanka’s opposition parties have criticised the DDR plan for laying a heavier burden on the EPF and ETF, a move that Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe has defended.

“There is no better solution that is fair by everyone,” Weerasinghe said, speaking at the central bank’s monthly monetary policy review press conference on July 06, adding that a majority’s existing bank deposits also have to be taken into consideration.

“If you’re a member of the EPF, is it important to you to protect your existing funds to live now or to protect your future pension? To protect your pension, you have to live now. If there was a bank run, everyone including EPF members would lose what they currently have as well as their EPF,” he said.
The government’s DDR plan, as it exists now, balances these two scenarios and strives to protect the assets of all citizens, according to Weerasinghe.

The World Bank, it appears, agrees that a balance has been struck, though it is not directly involved in Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring efforts.
“I think it’s very good news that the DDR plan was passed by parliament,” said Hadad-zervos during the Q&A of Tuesday’s talk.

“On one side you want it to contribute to debt sustainability. But not to a point where people in the financial system are worried. I think the way it has been done and approved by parliament is a very good balance between these two,” he said. (Colombo/Jul19/2023)
